Award.AwardTitle: Continuous Assessment of the Response of Deep-Seated Landslides by Monitoring Basal Temperature (CoRDeaL)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Deep-seated landslides represent one of the most devastating natural hazards on earth, typically creeping at inappreciable velocities over several years, before suddenly collapsing often with high velocity movement and catastrophic results. They can have detrimental consequences to society, as they involve large-scale collapse, causing fatalities and often affecting transportation infrastructure. Notable examples of such catastrophic failures include, among others, the 1963 Vaiont landslide in Italy, which devastated an entire valley causing around 2000 casualties and rendering inactive the largest hydro-electric dam of Italy, the 1999 Jiufengershan Landslide in Taiwan and the 2014 Oso landslide in the U.S. What determines the stability of these landslides and the time of final collapse remains a key problem in landslide mechanics and natural hazard prediction and prevention. This project will investigate the physical processes that are thought to drive deep-seated landslides to catastrophic collapse, particularly focusing on whether the response of these landslides can be continuously assessed by monitoring the temperature of the sliding surface. <br/><br/>This project will assess potential for failure plane temperature to affect stability, and collect in-situ temperature data. It will focus on testing the hypothesis that the response of deep-seated landslides can be continuously assessed by enriching models with the material's thermal response, and monitoring the temperature of the sliding surface. This is envisioned to be achieved by combining theoretical and numerical approaches, experiments on material from an active landslide in Andorra, Europe, together with field data of displacement, piezometric level and temperature at the base of the landslide. The project aims at offering unique and transformative knowledge and technology on how deep-seated landslides would respond in long-term, multi-physical loading (i.e. including elevated temperatures, pressures, and deformation rates). The long-term objectives of this work would be to quantify the dominant processes driving deep-seated landslides to instability, and develop an operational protocol for this type of hazard. It is, therefore, envisioned that the outcomes of this pilot project could fuel a new approach in modeling, monitoring and assessing deep-seated landslides.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deep-seated landslides represent one of the most devastating natural hazards on earth, typically creeping at inappreciable velocities over several years before collapsing at catastrophic speeds. They can have detrimental consequences to society, causing fatalities and prone to affect transportation infrastructures. Currently, limited data-driven tools allow a time-dependent assessment of these landslides, mainly linking their motion with groundwater variations or forecasting the collapse time using the empirical inverse velocity?time approach. In this project, we validated that monitoring the basal temperature of a creeping landslide in Andorra, and fusing it with physics-based modeling, can offer predictive and control capabilities for the landslide?s response.

We have initially developped a theoretical predictive framework that considers the evolution of the basal temperature of the landslide and the thermal sensitivity of the clayey soil that comprises the sliding surface. This framework can be used to assess the evolution and stability of a landslide, and in order to validate its main thermally-driven assumption we installed a thermometer on the sliding surface of a creeping landslide in Andorraand collected core logs from the borehole where the instrumentaiton wwas installed. We have collected data since August 2018 and identified the basal stress?temperature space as the underlying unobserved phase space that determines the stability of the slope and allows us to forecast and control the landslide.

Following our theoretical and field work we tested experimentally the core logs and reported the results onn the material's thermal annd rate sensitivities. These allowed us to validate our theoretical suggestion that the thermal interplay between the material and the environment can drive the landslide. Following this controlled study we extended the framework to case studies with less in-situ instrumentations. Sofar we applied our model to four other cases, where temperature measurements are unavailable: the Vajont (Italy) and Mud Creek (California) collapsed landslides and the active Shuping landslide (China) and Reunion landslide (Italy). The project concluded that physics-based models can be trained in the same phase space and offer forecasting and control capabilities. We anticipate these results to be the starting point for a new era in monitoring, controlling, and forecasting deep-seated landslides, aiming at alleviating their devastating impact on society.
